docs.lead_paragraph: General Electric, still hobbled by high costs and sluggish sales in formerly stellar industrial businesses like power systems, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings were 11 percent lower than those of last year, and that full-year earnings would be $1.55 to $1.57 a share, the lowest range of analysts' estimates. The announcement, however, came at the end of a week of big acquisitions that have laid out a blueprint for a G.E. that will be less dependent on old-line businesses, and far more tied to fast-growing ones like health care and communications.

headline.main: G.E. Earnings Decline 11%; Key Product Lines Are Sluggish

docs.abstract: General Electric reports third-quarter net earnings fell 11 percent, to $3.65 billion, compared with $4.09 billion in 2002 period; says full-year earnings will be at lowest range of analysts' estimates; chief executive Jeffrey R Immelt says new acquisitions position GE for long-term, high-value growth; GE plans to aquire Amersham, British medical company, and make its chief executive, Sir William Castell, GE vice chairman and board member; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The American International Group agreed on Thursday to buy 9.9 percent of the PICC Property and Casualty Company, China's biggest property and casualty insurer, in a deal that underlines the allure of the Chinese insurance market. Chinese households have one of the world's highest savings rates, holding on to 40 percent of their incomes and typically putting almost all of it into the rickety, mostly government-owned banking system.

headline.main: A.I.G. Plans to Buy 9.9% Of Large Chinese Insurer

docs.lead_paragraph: Supervalu Inc., a food distributor and owner of the Shop 'n Save supermarkets, said yesterday that second-quarter net income rose 5.8 percent because of higher sales. Net income in the quarter ended Sept. 6 rose to $62.2 million, or 46 cents a share, from $58.8 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 5.8 percent, to $4.59 billion from $4.34 billion.

docs.lead_paragraph: Option Care Inc., a distributor of drugs and services to managed care providers, said it had a loss in the third quarter and would cut jobs because of slow sales. The chief executive, Raj Rai, blamed legislation to overhaul Medicare for the sluggish sales. Measures being debated in Congress would save Medicare as much as $15 billion over 10 years by cutting reimbursements for drugs administered by doctors. Concern about the changes is making customers cautious, reducing demand for Option Care's services and prompting the company to take steps to reduce expenses, mainly through job cuts, Mr. Rai said. Option Care is based in Buffalo Grove, Ill.

headline.main: FLUX AT MEDICARE BLAMED FOR LOSS AT OPTION CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: A Queens lawyer who bought a bungalow in Hawaii and a world-class wine collection while stealing from the accounts of disabled and mentally ill people he had been appointed to represent was sentenced yesterday to three to nine years in prison. The lawyer, Robert B. Kress, apologized after being sentenced by Justice James P. Griffin of State Supreme Court in Queens. Mr. Kress, 46, was disbarred after pleading guilty in May to stealing more than $2.1 million from 17 incapacitated people for whom he was a court-appointed legal guardian from 1997 to 2002.

headline.main: Prison Term For Guardian Who Stole From Clients

docs.abstract: Disbarred lawyer Robert B Kress is sentenced to three to nine years in prison for stealing more than $2.1 million from 17 court-appointed clients in New York City; clients were mentally ill and disabled (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Weirton Steel Corporation plans to cut 950 jobs and terminate pension and health care benefits for about 10,000 former workers and their dependents. Under a revamping plan filed yesterday with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wheeling, W.Va., the company said it would create a new pension plan for remaining employees. Weirton said it hopes to remain an independent producer, but it is pursuing strategies to ensure its long-term survival in some form. The company filed for bankruptcy protection in May. Weirton, which is based in Weirton, W.Va., employs about 3,500 people.

headline.main: WEIRTON STEEL PLANS TO CUT PENSION BENEFITS FOR 10,000

docs.lead_paragraph: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had reached a $540,000 settlement with a former executive who filed a lawsuit against the company asserting that he was fired after he raised concerns about accounting fraud and a rigged marketing test in Burger King restaurants. Under the terms of the agreement, the employee, Matthew Whitley, will receive $100,000 in cash, approximately $140,000 in severance benefits, including health insurance, and $300,000 to pay lawyer's fees. Mr. Whitley has also agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which are investigating possible improper business practices at Coke. Neither Coke nor Mr. Whitley would comment further on the settlement.
docs.abstract: Coca-Cola Co reaches $540,000 settlement with Matthew Whitley, who filed lawsuit charging that company fired him after he raised concerns about accounting fraud and rigged marketing test in Burger King restaurants; Whitley agrees to cooperate with federal prosecutors and Securities and Exchange Commission, which is investigating possible improper business practices at Coke; sued Coke's fountain division, asserting unit engaged in $2 billion in accounting fraud, created slush funds, manipulated its inventories and disciminated against minorities (M)
